Following the hint, we want to find a straight line that is below
$y=sin(x)$ with minimal error.

To do this, we require the straight line to pass through $y=sin(x)$ at
both \emph{x=0} and \emph{x=Ï/2}, which are the endpoints of the domain
of integration.

Since \emph{y=sin(0)=0} at \emph{x=0}, we look for a straight line that
passes through the origin with formula \emph{y=$f$(x)=cx}. Then we put
\emph{x=Ï/2}, \emph{y=sin(Ï/2)=1} to find \emph{1=cÏ/2}, so
\emph{c=2/Ï}.

Note that the slope of the line \emph{c=2/Ï\textless{}1}, while the
initial slope of \emph{y=sin(x)} is given by \emph{cos(0)=1}, so the
linear function \emph{y=2/Ï x} is really below \emph{y=sin(x)} in the
interval $[0, \pi/2]$

Hence, we can deduce the following inequalities:

\begin{align*}
\frac{2}{\pi} x &\leq \sin x \\ \Rightarrow 
-a \sin x &\leq -\frac{2a}{\pi} x  \\ \Rightarrow 
e^{-a \sin x} &\leq e^{-\frac{2a}{\pi} x} \end{align*}

because \emph{a\textgreater{}0} and $e^x$ is a strictly increasing
function.

So by comparison, we obtain

\begin{align*}
\int_0^{\pi/2} e^{-a \sin x} dx &\leq \int_0^{\pi/2} e^{-\frac{2a}{\pi} x} dx \\
&= -\frac{\pi}{2a} \left[ e^{-\frac{2a}{\pi} x} \right]_0^{\pi/2} \\
&= -\frac{\pi}{2a} \left(e^{-a}-1\right) \\
&= \frac{\pi}{2a} \left(1- e^{-a}\right) < \frac{\pi}{2a} \end{align*}

because $e^{-a} > 0$ for any \emph{a}.
